reviews.review_msg: Amir is very passionate about the subject, but he is the most disorganized prof I've ever had. He was late to every class, and we had to cover 3/4 of the course work, and evaluations, in the last 2.5 weeks of class. Also, the grammar on the exams was terrible, and he cut the final exam time frm 3hrs to 2 w/o notice. A nice guy and a terrible prof.

Amir is absolutely wonderful.  I was afraid that this course was going to be horrible, but he honestly makes everything so clear that it shouldn't be a problem for anyone!  He makes you laugh, he's very fun and obviously VERY passionate about the subject.  Truly a fantastic prof!
Amir is great prof!! He is really really really kind! Really really patient even though evetones keep asking him the same question! And i love the TA as well! Xinren is the best TA so far!

Awesome prof! He is so cute. Always remember to say "Good Afternoon!" :D His quizes are the same as what he posts online, his final is long but easy, the project is so easy-you just have to follow his example. Overall, loved him! I was afraid of stats until I had him.

Amir is a passionate and funny guy! Xinren is also a good TA. If you miss lecture, there are some notes online, however, Amir uses the board a lot. He'll write questions that WILL help you a lot during your exams. Practice is key. Quizzes are given periodically, which aren't too bad. You don't need to be good at math to ace this course!! Good luck!

One of the worst professors I've had yet at SFU. He is fairly incomprehensible in explaining the material. He more or less just regurgitate the content found in the textbook, but in a far less coherent manner. Further, you must attend 4 hours of lectures and 1 tutorial hour per week, despite the course only be worth 3-credits. Just terrible.

Amir is knowledgeable, relates well to students, patient, and makes stats "fun". I struggled with math ever since high school and to pull an A outta this class seemed impossible. Go to lecture, tutorials, do your homework and it's a doable A. Definitely one of the best profs at SFU!
I really had fun in his class! Awesome professor! Super helpful and very patient with his students. We will miss you Amir! Thanks for a great semester!
VERY patient. Does not yell at the class when being asked the same question 100 times. He tries his best so that everyone understands the course material.
I am not a huge math person and I didn't think that I would like this class. I ended up getting a B+ in this class when I thought I would get a C and I really, really enjoyed this class. I LOVE AMIR!

He was awesome! I thought this class would be hard at first, since the name was empirical research methods. It wasn't as hard as I thought it would be. He explains it very well, gives you great examples and the TAs knew what they were doing. Project was really easy, he basically showed you how to do it step by step. I got an A- in the end, not hard

Excellent prof and makes a hard subject easy for everyone.  Plus, he is very entertaining and makes sure all students understand the concepts.  I actually ended up looking forward to his lectures while I had him in the summer semester

Amir is GREAT! Im getting an A in his class, havent done the final yet but so far so good. He really teaches, he wants to make sure everyone understands, he repeats and explains things a lot and very interactive with the class. Easy to ask him questions and he's kinda funny too sometimes. Read the book and go to lecture = A

Quite possibly the best teacher I've ever had in university. Tells you exactly (I am being literal) what will be on the exam. I hate math, but he made statistics easy. I'm currently getting an A+. Might get it too if I do the way I am on the project and final. If you take this course, take it with Amir. Crystal clear.

The course has very dry content overall, but she just made it more even more dry. Lecture slides are very disorganized and repetitive. She mentions that lectures are mandatory in order to do well in this course, but her lecture slides consists of word by word context from the textbook and it seems like she didn't update the page numbers on slides.

The lectures were a bit dry and attendance was taken for them, but it counts towards your grade too. No surprises in this class and when you get to the actual  data analyzing it isn't as dry. A bit disorganized, but not the worst prof at SFU at all.

Terrible prof, terrible TAs would not recommend taking anything with her. She is very disorganized,  very confusing and her lectures are extremely dry and even though I attended 80% of the classes I still could not tell you anything about what we were supposed to have learnt.
She isn't a very good public speaker and her lectures can be very dry. However, the material isn't very complicated to understand and she makes clear what is important to know for quizzes/exams.

Shes a really sweet prof who color codes her handouts because she knows it helps you stay organized! She always has comics, videos and other illustrations w her slides to help you follow along, shows you the answers right after the quiz so you know what you got. *Just need to know the definitions! CMNS-260 would have been WAY harder w another prof!

Really nice prof that cares so much about the research and the topic she teaches. She repeats a lot in her slides but she makes sure that you understand what she says. She's easy to follow and I really enjoyed her lectures. She got me interested in her subject.

I attended nearly every lecture, and I have no idea why. When she wasn't rambling on about how there wasn't enough time to cover all the material in the course, she was doing overkill on the material she had already presented. Painful to listen to. The TAs were the only saving grace of this course. Way too much work for few results.

Garbage lectures, brutal public speaker, just bumbles through her scattered powerpoint slides. I wanted to die in every lecture I attended and I love school. Most difficult person I've ever been forced to listen to.

Nice lady, bad speaker. If you have a hard time listening to people say "um" over and over again, I'd avoid this lecture. However, attending the lecture isn't really necessary as she makes her material available online, and the TAs are all very nice and helpful.
boring lectures, no fun at all .dont go, just stay at home and read your books

Fred is a great prof, easy to follow, sometimes boring but always stays on track with lectures. The bi-weekly quizzes are easy and straight from lecture material, honestly the textbook is pointless. Can't speak to the exam because it was cancelled (snow) but based on everything else I would definitely recommend Fred.

I LOVE Fred. He is definitely my favourite prof at SFU. He knows what he's talking about and is always open to questions and super easy to talk to.  Sometimes the lectures were a bit bland but it is a research methods class so what do you expect. Has bi-weekly (ish) quizzes worth 5% each and drops your lowest one (woohoo!) which boosts your grade

I came into 260 thinking that the class would be horrible and boring. There were some weeks that proved this theory. However, Fred was a great prof that did his best to make the lecture material as interesting and accessible as possible. Also a nice looking guy, which is a plus!

A model example of a professor. His kindness to his students is reflected in the organization and intention in class design. Assignments and quizzes were very well spaced and manageable. It is a nurturing model for gradual learning. I hate beastly tests that quiz your knowledge all at once. My favorite lecture was the emotional contagion one!

Structures the course well. It's not that difficult and as long as you follow the guidelines in the assignments, you should do OK. Quizzes aren't that difficult either and they are all multiple-choice. Plus I had Yuji as the TA and it's like she came from heaven, she is the best! Great class, especially for a Q! Completely do-able.

He needs to work on his presentation skills. Too much stuttering that it gets distracting. Also, he needs to revise his assignment criteria. Too confusing to follow and sometimes, HE doesn't even follow it. Overall, it's very term-reliant so be sure to read the book. Also, go to labs as it's vital for the assignments. Lectures are meh.
Nice prof. Likes what he teaches. Assignments are hard to follow. To many details perhaps. Exams are fair.

Great prof, but work intensive. Although it is meant to be a Q class, the class work load is just too over loaded. I'd dropped the class but I guess the school don't have enough prof for this course. I'll eventually have to take the course with him again :/

I have mixed feeling for him, overall he display care for his students..os so it seems..but his way of teaching & explaining thing are so confusing. He runs through thing so fast. You are left with bigger confusion after class. Then again, math is not my forte.

I thought he was a nice guy.I really did.Whenever I shared long convos w/him after lecture,he would appear to be so nice&caring.Turns out he's the opposite.Im hurt.Says below"when he thinks he's right he's right & he will explain that in terms of how wrong you are"-->very true.he's obnoxious/rude/not understanding/cannot teach/makes easy stuff hard
David was "OKAY" but over all, this course was so unhelpful and hard.if u r not a "math" guy,don't ever!EVER! "EVER" take this course
No Comments
always willing to help. although sometimes he answers questions assuming that he understood the question. if you have a question, make sure you repeat it a couple of times.
Shows passion in what he teaches, and tries to help students. Boring lectures but david provide tests and assignments that fits the level of the textbook
The course, if you study each week, can be quite insightful and a good grade, if you do the work, can be gotten.  The prof tries very hard to relate material, and help you learn... Good experience.
Not to bad of a course, pretty easy, as long as you study.

Chris is easily the most human and most helpful prof I've had in the CMNS dept. He takes boring brutally dull material and somehow makes it all quite palatable. I'm almost done at SFU, but if I took more courses I'd take anything he's teaching.

Chris is thee best! I was really worried about taking this class, but he broke everything down so well and explained as clear as possible, making this one of my absolute favourite courses :) Teach more upper levels, Chris!!

Chris was one of the best profs I've had at SFU. I honestly wasn't looking forward to this class at all and it ended up being one of my favourites in my whole degree because of his teaching methods. Chris is super easy-going, well-organized, and genuinely cares about his students. His lectures are informative, and sometimes kinda funny!ThanksChris!

Chris was an amazing Prof! I took this class in the Summer during intersession. He was one of the best Professors I have ever had! Went out of his way to make sure everyone knew what they were doing in the lab. Marking was straight forward, fair, and honestly easy. 3 assignments, 2 tests, and a final. Easy read for the textbook. TAKE IT WITH HIM!
LOOOVE HIM 3 I would take every course with him if I could! Probs one of my favourite proffs!

Chris is so enthusiastic and encouraging! His energy  is infectious and he really got me stoked on messing around with SPSS (even though I'm not that into computers).  I think he may be the best prof I've had so far at SFU!

Chris is a super kind proff. He's always wiling to help. He always seems to have a smile on his face; he's very personable. Since I took the course intersession, he was the professor and the lab instructor. He explains the material really well and makes sure everyone in the class understands. In labs, we practiced what he taught in lecture. EASY!!!
repeats what's in courseware, not informative with regards to  assignments
